Dear Michael Centi:
Attached is the Special Investigation Report for the above referenced facility. Due to the
violations identified in the report, a written corrective action plan is required. The
corrective action plan is due 15 days from the date of this letter and must include the
following:
• How compliance with each rule will be achieved.
• For any repeat violations, why the prior corrective action plan did not result
in compliance.
• Who is directly responsible for implementing the corrective action for each
violation.
• Specific time frames for each violation as to when the action steps will be
completed or implemented.
• How continuing compliance will be maintained once compliance is
achieved.
• The signature of the responsible party and a date.
If you desire technical assistance in addressing these issues, please feel free to contact
me. In any event, the corrective action plan is due within 15 days. Failure to submit an
acceptable corrective action plan will result in disciplinary action.
Please review the enclosed documentation for accuracy and contact me with any
questions. In the event that I am not available, and you need to speak to someone
immediately, please contact the area manager at 616-204-6992.

III. INVESTIGATION
Rule Code Program statement
Title
Rule Code & CCI Rule 400.4109
Section (1) An institution shall have and follow a current written program
Description statement which specifically addresses all of the following:
(c) Policies and procedures pertaining to admission, care,
safety, and supervision, methods for addressing residents’ needs,
implementation of treatment plans, and discharge of residents.
Violation Potential Rule or Statute Violation
Type
Allegation In March or April 2024, staff used marijuana with Youth C and
Youth D who were placed in the program. This occurred in a
company van.
The agency is not completing incident reports as required.
Investigation Counselor was interviewed at the facility face to face on
8/20/2024 in collaboration with MDHHS worker. She reported
Administrator 1 and Administrator 2 were not on site and had no
idea when they would return. She reported being aware of part of
the allegations but had no firsthand information to share. She
reported Staff 1 was terminated from employment at the facility
over the allegations Staff 1 smoked marijuana during an outing
with a couple of youth. She was unable to provide the date of the
incident or the date of Staff 1’s termination. She reported being
aware of the incident with Staff 1 when Staff 3 informed Counselor
of the incident. Counselor reported Staff 3 left employment at the
facility a few days ago.
Youth D was interviewed at the facility face to face on
8/20/2024 in collaboration with MDHHS worker. Youth D
reported being on the outing when Staff 1 smoked marijuana while
driving the facility van. Youth D reported knowing what marijuana
smells like and what type of smoke it makes because it is different
than tobacco smoke. Youth D reported Staff 1 smoked the
marijuana in a vape pen. Youth D reported Youth C was present
in the van and reported the incident to Staff 3.
2

Staff 3 was interviewed via phone on 8/22/2024 in
collaboration with MDHHS worker. Staff 3 reported Youth C told
Staff 3 that Staff 1 smoked “weed” with youth on an outing to the
movies. Staff 3 was unsure of the date of the outing but believed it
was early spring. Staff 3 reported telling Administrator 1 and
Administrator 2 about the smoking incident believing the
administrators would tell the state. Administrator 1 and
Administrator 2 told Staff 3 “it was alright”. Staff 3 doesn’t believe
there was an incident report about the smoking incident with Staff
1, but Administrator 1 and Administrator 2 knew about the incident
the following day. Staff 3 reported being trained on reporting
incidents and believed that only one person needs to report an
incident because “someone” will take care of it.
Staff 1 was interviewed via phone on 8/23/2024 in
collaboration with MDHHS worker. She reported working at the
facility from January 2024 to the end of March 2024 when she quit
working. She reported part of the reason she left the facility was
the “drama” between herself and Staff 3 over Staff 3’s report Staff
1 was smoking marijuana with youth in the van during an outing.
Staff 1 reported this was a false claim and she never smoked
marijuana in the van or while working. Staff 1 reported there was
an internal investigation and she left employment prior to the
investigation being finished so she is unaware of the outcome.
Staff 1 reported working the shift with Staff 3 and taking several
youth on an outing to the movies in the facility van. She reported
Human Resources informed her that Staff 3 and some of the
youth reported Staff 1 was smoking marijuana a week after the
outing. Staff 1 reported finding out about this after receiving an
email informing her she was suspended. Staff 1 admitted to
having a vape pen and “taking a puff” during the outing but it was
tobacco and not marijuana. Staff 1 reported knowing that older
staff would use a vape in the bathroom or office and accepted that
it was inappropriate but if others were doing it, it must be alright.
Staff 1 reported there was never a formal process for filling out
incident reports. Staff 1 reported there was never a formal process
for filling out incident reports or reporting to MDHHS and she
never received training on a process for doing so.
Staff 2 was interviewed via phone on 9/10/2024 in
collaboration with MDHHS worker. Staff 2 reported never
witnessing staff vaping
Administrator 2 was interviewed via phone on 9/10/2024 in
collaboration with MDHHS worker. Administrator 2 reported
being informed of the allegations but never speaking with Staff 1.
3

Staff 1 terminated her employment during the investigation. He
reported understanding that Staff 1 smoked after receiving peer
pressure from the two youth and had admitted during the HR
investigation that she smoked with the youth. Staff 1 was never
drug tested during the investigation. Administrator 2 denied being
aware of any staff using a vape while working and never being
told that staff are using vapes at work. Administrator 2 reported an
incident report would have been completed for allegations made
of staff using marijuana and youth having sexual contact, but no
incident report document was provided.
Documents Reviewed:
8/17/24 On-call MDHHS worker’s notes on contact with Youth
C. Youth C confirmed having a consensual relationship with Youth
E but that they never had sex at the facility. Youth C reported
Youth E became pregnant and had an abortion. Once the facility
found out about the situation, Youth C was discharged from the
facility, but Youth E was allowed to stay.
Lighthouse A Step Forward Resident Handbook A transitional
Living Program dated November 2023. It is documented that
House guidelines outline no drug, alcohol, or tobacco use at the
facility.
Lighthouse Sanctuary Basic Center Resident Handbook
dated February 2024. It is documented Basic house guidelines
state the use of alcohol, illegal drugs, or tobacco are not permitted
and if found on youth the guardian/parent will be notified.
Code of Ethical Conduct for staff without a date. This
document outlines that the facility is a smoke free environment for
all employees and visitors. This covers the smoking of any
tobacco products, vaping products, and the use of oral tobacco
products. It is also stated that smoking is prohibited in company
vehicles at all times.
Lighthouse workplace investigation – Staff 1 dated March 11,
2024. This document outlines the allegations of an incident
involving Staff 1 smoking marijuana with youth in the facility
vehicle. It is documented that on 3/14/24 Administrator 1 received
a phone call from Administrator 2 about being informed by Staff 3
that Staff 1 had smoked marijuana in the vehicle with two youth
present during an outing on 3/8/24 after the two youth
(unidentified in this report) informed Staff 3 of the incident. This
document is a breakdown of Administrator 1’s investigation of the
allegations involving Staff 1. The recommendations outlined by
4

Administrator 3 for this investigation involve the entire department
to receive intensive training on professional accountability and
boundaries, training on mandatory reporter requirements,
corrective action be issued to Staff 3 for not reporting to Staff 3’s
manager, a corrective action for Staff 4 for informing the youth
about the allegations, and an in-person review of the policy that
was written to protect youth and staff.
Lighthouse incident report form policy and procedures dated
2/1/23. It is documented that wherever an incident occurs at any
Lighthouse office, program location, or at a lighthouse related
event, meeting, or outing, employees witnessing the incident must
complete all incident reporting procedures. Employees are to
complete an incident report within one hour of the end of the
incident and inform the immediate supervisor as soon as possible
before the end of the workday or immediately in the morning of the
next day. An incident is described as an occurrence involving a
youth, volunteer, or staff’s safety that is potentially compromised
in any of the locations mentioned above.
Incident reports provided by the facility covering January
through August 2024. There were no incident reports for the
reported sexual contact between youth or for Staff 1 using
marijuana.
Staff 1’s personnel file: Documentation indicates Staff 1 was
hired on 1/25/2024 and there is no disciplinary action documents
in the file. Administrator 2 reported there are no training logs for
Staff 1 documented.
Staff 2’s personnel file: Documentation indicates Staff 2 was
hired on 3/3/23 and there is no disciplinary action documents in
the file. Documentation indicates Staff 2 completed 10 hours of
training since being hired although none of the training was
specific to drug use, or incident reporting.
Staff 3’s personnel file: Documentation indicates Staff 3 was
hired on 11/29/23 and there is no disciplinary action documents in
the file. Staff 3 is documented as completing 25.25 hours of
training since being hired. The training completed is documented
as the following. Active shooter, assessment tools and techniques,
case management in the program, employee wellness, navigating
ethical challenges, preventing and de-escalating crisis situations,
equity and engaging youth impacted by sex trafficking and
exploitation, evidence based practice series, harm reduction,
trauma informed care, identify and responding to sexually
5

exploited children, implementing harm reduction, motivational
interviewing, new grantee orientation Q & A, outreach &
engagement strategies to captivate, draw, & involve youth,
positive youth development, runaway and homeless youth and
education partnership, safety with youth and staff in the program,
understanding and managing personal/professional boundaries,
understanding systems of power and privilege, and working with
LANTINX families and their LGBTQIA+ youth.
Analysis The agency is found in noncompliance as during interviews and
review of documentation Staff 1 did not follow the facility policy of
not using tobacco products while working as outlined in the Code
of Ethical Conduct for staff policy. Additionally, the facility did not
follow the Lighthouse incident report form policy and procedures.
None of the incidents were documented on incident reports as
required by the facility’s own policy.
Conclusion Violation Established
Rule Code Sufficiency of Staff
Title
Rule Code & CCI Rule 400.4126
Section The licensee shall have a sufficient number of administrative,
Description supervisory, social service, direct care, and other staff on duty to
perform the prescribed functions required by these administrative
rules and in the agency’s program statement and to provide for
the continual needs, protection, and supervision of residents
Violation Potential Rule or Statute Violation
Type
Allegation In February 2024, Youth A and Youth B had sexual intercourse in
the bathroom. Staff went to the basement, leaving the youth
unattended at the time.
In April or May 2024, Youth C and Youth D had sexual
intercourse. Youth D became pregnant and sought emancipation
from the courts to terminate the baby. She was successfully
emancipated, and the facility assisted Youth D with terminating
the pregnancy.
In July 2024, Youth F and Youth G had sexual intercourse. This
resulted in a lack of proper supervision. At the time of the incident,
there were 8 youth and 1 staff.
Investigation Complainant was interviewed via phone on 9/18/2024. She
reported receiving the allegations from youth at the facility during
an audit she was conducting. She had no further information to
provide.
6

Counselor was interviewed at the facility face to face on
8/20/2024 in collaboration with MDHHS worker. She reported
Administrator 1 and Administrator 2 were not on site and had no
idea when they would return. She reported being aware of part of
the allegations but had no firsthand information to share.
Youth A and Youth E were interviewed at the facility face to
face on 8/20/2024 in collaboration with MDHHS worker. Both
reported feeling well and safe at the facility but refused to answer
further questions.
Youth D was interviewed at the facility face to face on
8/20/2024 in collaboration with MDHHS worker. Youth D
reported being at the facility for the second time this summer and
described the first time as “good” but the second time “bad”. Youth
D reported the “bad” as Administrator 1 and Administrator 2 have
a rule to not kick out any youth regardless of the violations which
is causing chaos in the facility. Youth D reported youth engaging
in sex at the facility as the chaos. Youth D reported some youth
speak in a violent manner to others in the facility because they
know they will not be removed from the facility. Youth D believed
the youth are “running the show” at the facility and don’t pay
attention to the rules or staff. Youth D reported Youth E was a
roommate who had sex with Youth C. Youth D reported both
Youth C and Youth E were alone when this occurred, but she was
unable to give more specific information. Youth C and Youth E
were never caught by staff according to Youth D and neither
admitted to having sex.
Youth D reported Youth F and Youth G engaged in sex at the
facility and Youth G told staff about the sex. Youth D reported
Youth G informed Administrator 2 about the sex with Youth F but
Administrator 2 “did nothing about it”. Youth D reported there are
two programs within the facility and Youth D is in the A Step
Forward(ASF) which allows youth to leave during the day and
return at curfew. This allows the youth to attend school and work
after school. Youth D believed the programs changed when
Administrator 1 and Administrator 2 started their positions and
now Administrator 2 doesn’t believe any reports of sex between
youth if it is not caught on camera. Youth D feels safe at the
facility because Youth D is able to get away from the facility during
the day and this allows her to “stay in my own lane”.
Attempts to contact Youth C via telephone were made on 8/21/24
and 9/3/24 but all were unsuccessful.
7

Youth G was interviewed at her foster home face to face on
8/20/2024 in collaboration with MDHHS worker. Youth G
reported leaving the facility on 8/2/24 and described the facility as
having staff that were “alright”. Youth G believed staff were
supervising the youth. Youth G reported having some issues with
staff but was unable to recall the names of the staff. Youth G
reported “something happened between me and Youth F at the
facility”. Youth G refused to go into details and asked why she was
being interviewed so much. Youth G reported being interviewed
by staff and others about the incident with Youth F and suggested
that everyone should know about it by now. Youth G reported the
safety plan put into place was that Youth F could not speak with
Youth F any longer however, Youth G also reported they kept
talking with each other. Youth G reported Administrator 2 and
Staff 3 spoke to Youth F and Youth G about the incident several
times. Youth G reported staff tried to keep Youth F and Youth G
apart, but it didn’t work because staff didn’t really care about
keeping them apart. Youth G reported none of the other youth
were engaging in sex at the facility. Youth G reported she had a
room right across the hall from Youth F during this time. Youth G
reported feeling safe at the facility and having Youth F’s needs
(food and shelter) taken care of.
Staff 3 was interviewed via phone on 8/22/2024 in
collaboration with MDHHS worker. She reported ending her
employment at the facility on 8/11/24 when she found out about
Youth F and Youth G engaging in sex while Staff 3 was
supervising the facility alone. She reported reading that Youth F
gave Youth G a “blow job” in Youth F’s journal. She reported this
act between Youth F and Youth G took place on 7/12/24. She
reported being the “whistle blower” when she reported the
incident. After telling Administrator 2 the information Staff 3
learned, Administrator 2 informed Staff 3 “anyone could have
written that”. Staff 3 reported watching a video of Youth G trying to
get Youth F into Youth G’s bedroom and being told by
Administrator 2 to “remain unbiased in these situations” and
“nonjudgmental”. This was a video dated 8/8 or 8/9. She gave the
licensing worker (unidentified) a copy of text messages Staff 3 had
with Administrator 2 on 8/10/24. Staff 3 believed Administrator 2
gave some of the information about the incident between Youth F
and Youth G to the licensing worker (unidentified). She reported
“begging” for help in supervising the youth but being told by
Administrator 2 that the ratio could be 1:10 during waking hours.
She believed staff alone were not able to protect the youth as
required and at the time of the reported incident, she was the only
8

staff supervising 8 to 9 youth. She reported working 10-hours at
times and up to 12-hours if needed. Staff 3 reported the staffing
problems began when Administrator 2 began working at the
facility and the number of staff dropped from 10 to 5. Staff 3
reported Administrator 2 would set a rule and want staff to enforce
the rule but when Administrator 2 was working he would allow the
youth to break the rule in front of staff.
Staff 1 was interviewed via phone on 8/23/2024 in
collaboration with MDHHS worker. She reported working at the
facility from January 2024 to March 2024 when she quit. Staff 1
reported Staff 3 reported Youth E and Youth C were involved in an
unhealthy relationship but was unable to provide any further
information about this unhealthy relationship. Staff 1 reported
observing Youth E and Youth B come out of a bathroom together
and inform other youth that Youth E and Youth B engaged in sex.
Staff 1 reported this was never reported nor was any action taken.
Staff 1 reported the facility is understaffed most of the time and
staff felt overworked.
Staff 2 was interviewed via phone on 9/10/2024 in
collaboration with MDHHS worker. She reported working at the
facility from March 2023 to February 2024. She reported working
alone on numerous shifts with the responsibility of supervising 10
to 12 youth at a time. Staff 2 didn’t believe she was able to provide
the level of supervision the youth required and still complete all of
the other tasks such as conducting intakes of new youth, getting
items for youth, making meals, and completing paperwork. Staff 2
reported making a report to Administrator 1 and Administrator 2
about the need for more than one staff supervising at a time and
the issues the youth were presenting. Staff 2 would have to break
up fights alone and would call management for help. She reported
because management’s response was she was told to figure it
out, she left her position at the facility. Staff 2 reported Youth A
and Youth B having sexual interaction in the bathroom occurred
just prior to Staff 2 leaving the facility. She was able to recall
Youth A but struggled to identify Youth B. After viewing the
camera footage, she observed Youth A going into the bathroom
followed a couple of minutes later by Youth B. However, the intern
who was with Staff 2 made noise down the hallway and Youth B
didn’t enter the bathroom. Staff 2 reported having to get
something from the basement and when returning observed Youth
B coming out of the bathroom followed by Youth A a few minutes
later. This occurred on a Saturday and Staff 2 reported the
incident to Administrator 2. Administrator 2 told Staff 2 to complete
a write up, which is a corrective action plan. She believed there
9

was a meeting about the incident on Monday and both youth
received a write up. Staff 2 described the process of dealing with
youth breaking the rules as staff completing an incident report,
developing a corrective action plan for the youth, and having the
youth sign a paper acknowledging their responsibility. Staff 2
reported the youth ignored the policy of not touching each other
even after staff and management spoke with the youth. She
believed the youth just didn’t care about the rules because there
were no consequences for breaking rules.
Administrator 1 was interviewed via phone on 9/10/2024 in
collaboration with MDHHS worker. In regard to the allegation
(February Youth A and Youth B in the bathroom), Administrator 1
reported investigating the allegations and they were never
supported by Youth A and Youth B of which both denied the
allegations. Administrator 1 stated the incident was not reported
by staff but then stated staff did report the youth were in the
bathroom together. Administrator 2 reported it was only
speculation that Youth A and Youth B were having sex in the
bathroom. He reported finding out about the youth in the bathroom
together when conducting a random check of camera footage.
Administrator 1 reported an incident report should have been
completed and that he is seeking this document. In regard to the
allegation (April or May Youth C and Youth E had sexual
intercourse and Youth E became pregnant ending in an abortion),
Administrator 1 reported Youth C and Youth E having sexual
intercourse at the facility was never substantiated as the youth
didn’t admit to it, and because they were both in the ASF program,
they would be off site often. Administrator 1 reported if it did occur,
it would have been outside of the facility, and he was aware of the
pregnancy but it again stated it was outside of the facility. In
regard to the allegation (July Youth F and Youth G had sexual
intercourse), Administrator 1 reported Youth G informed
Administrator 1 that Youth G performed oral sex on Youth F
therefore there was no vaginal penetration. Administrator 1
reported Staff 3 reported Youth F and Youth G were in the
bathroom together. He reported an incident report was completed.
Administrator 1 reported the ratio during waking hours is 1 staff for
10 youth (1:20 during sleeping hours) and that this is within the
licensing requirement. He reported staff should always be in a
close position to the youth and if needing to move to another area
of the facility, staff should gather all of the youth together and
move them to the same area staff will be in. He reported staff
have laptop computers which are tied into the camera system so
they can take the laptop with them and still monitor the youth. He
reported staffing has been an issue and the facility is working on
10

getting a second staff on every shift. He reported understanding
there can be a lack of supervision at times but they are still within
the ratio in the policy.
Parent 1 was interviewed via phone on 8/20/2024 in
collaboration with MDHHS worker. Parent 1 reported Youth B is
lodged in a Juvenile Facility in Florida at this time.
Administrator 2 was interviewed via video conference on
9/24/2024. He reported the facility only keeps video recording for
30 days before the recording is erased. He also reported the
efforts being made to increase the staffing ratio to one staff for
every 3 youth. Currently, the facility is attempting to fill all vacant
positions and has several potential applicants. He reported there
are several position offerings, and they hope to be hiring several
individuals very soon. The facility has increased the pay for these
positions along with increased compensation and other incentives.
To provide increased supervision at this time, they are providing
incentives for staff who are willing to work additional shifts until
hiring is completed. The facility is working hand in hand with the
HR department for screenings and interviews in an effort to hire
the most qualified individuals. He also reported a belief that a ratio
of 1:3 is the most workable and will provide the level of
supervision to keep youth safe. Currently, there are several other
individuals (managers, counselors, and interns) present during the
daytime to support staff. These other individuals are not counted
as part of the ratio.
Several attempts were made to contact Youth B who is
currently lodged in a Juvenile facility in Florida. Phone calls
were made on 8/21/24 and 9/3/24 with email attempts made on
9/5/24, 9/6/24, and 9/10/24.
Video Review:
Since the facility only keeps video recording for 30 days the only
video available is for 7/12/24 (they saved this video because of
the allegations. Video recording for 8/8/24 and 8/9/24 is no longer
available and census logs indicated neither Youth F nor Youth G
were in the program at that time. Youth F was discharged on
7/22/24 and Youth G discharged on 8/2/24.
7/12/24 Video recording. The time stamp indicates it is 11:00 pm.
The view is from the corner of the dining room facing towards the
center of the room. The hallway leading to the art room is visible
and the bathroom door is on the left of that hallway. There are no
individuals visible on the recording at this time. Youth F and an
11

unidentified youth enters the dining room (11:01) from the left side
hallway and sits at the dining room table. Only the entrance to this
hallway is visible. Approximately a half a minute later, Youth F
stands up and goes down the left side hallway (just the entrance
visible). Youth F followed by Youth G then come from the left side
hallway and both walk into the other hallway with the bathroom
and Youth F enters the bathroom first followed by Youth G,
shutting the door behind themselves (approximately 11:02:45).
The bathroom door opens but no one is seen and then the door
shuts again. At 11:03:46 Youth F comes out of the bathroom and
runs to his bedroom. Within a matter of seconds Youth F comes
out of his bedroom and runs back to the bathroom. Other youth
enter the dining room and one youth sits at the dining table. Staff
3 is seen entering the dining room from the left hallway about two
minutes later. There are two other youth with her. Staff 3 leaves
the dining room a few minutes later taking all but 1 youth with her.
Youth F comes out of the bathroom and engages with another
male youth in the hallway. Youth F then goes into the left hallway
with the other male youth. Approximately 3 minutes later, Youth G
comes out of the bathroom and walks into the art room at the end
of the hallway. Overall, the incident lasted approximately 10
minutes.
Documents Reviewed:
8/17/24 On-call MDHHS worker’s notes on contact with Youth
C. Youth C confirmed having a consensual relationship with Youth
E but that they never had sex at the facility. Youth C reported
Youth E became pregnant and had an abortion. Once the facility
found out about the situation, Youth C was discharged from the
facility, but Youth E was allowed to stay.
8/23/24 MDHHS worker was able to contact Youth F. Youth F
reported numerous people were doing different things at the
facility when he was staying there. Youth F reported doing “stuff”
with Youth G and they were able to get away with it because staff
were never around. Once a female staff (unidentified) tried to
intervene by talking and separating Youth F and Youth G. Youth F
reported youth will go into the bathroom if they want to engage in
“stuff”. He reported never feeling safe at the facility because the
people there were “crazy”.
Lighthouse A Step Forward Resident Handbook A transitional
Living Program dated November 2023. This document outlines
the guidelines, expectations, and mission of A Step Forward
(ASF) program. This program is a voluntary program which youth
can end at any time. Youth are to be in the facility by curfew at
12

9:30 pm daily during the orientation level and youth are not
allowed to spend the night outside of the facility with the exception
of holidays or special circumstances. Once reaching level one, the
curfew moves to 10:30 pm or 11:00 pm depending on the age of
the youth. Level two and level three have a curfew of 10:30 pm,
11:30 pm, or 12:30 am depending on the youth’s age. Youth are
to refrain from physical contact, sexual contact, or physical
aggression towards other youth in the facility. Youth are not
allowed in other youth’s bedrooms and the bedroom door is not
allowed to be locked while occupying the room. Romantic
relationships between youth are not allowed.
Lighthouse Sanctuary Basic Center Resident Handbook
dated February 2024. This program is a voluntary program which
youth can end at any time. Youth are to refrain from physical
contact, sexual contact, or physical aggression. Youth only have
permission to be in the bedroom they are assigned to, and their
room may be searched at any time by staff.
Lighthouse Staff, Intern, and Volunteer Handbook dated
4/2023. This document outlines the responsibilities for different
team members in the program and it notes that Youth Specialists
are to be mentors for youth who are at risk of sexual exploitation,
victims and survivors of sexual exploitation. Youth in the programs
are not to go into other youth’s bedrooms and only one youth in
the bathroom at a time. Further documentation indicates staff are
to report suspected cases of abuse or neglect.
Lighthouse RHV Sanctuary Program Resident Supervision
dated 7/10/2024. This document outlines the ratio for youth when
awake as 1 staff for 10 youth and during sleeping hours 1 staff for
20 youth. This document states, “This ratio formula for direct care
workers corresponds with Lighthouse's purpose and the needs of
the residents and shall assure the continual safety, protection, and
direct care and supervision of residents.” Cameras are used for
surveillance and are to be checked 3 times a week by the
Program Manager or Director. If an incident occurs, the video
should be checked, and a copy is to be stored for 30-days. Bed
checks must be completed no more than every 15-minutes by
staff in a random order.
Youth Census for A Step Forward program. This document
indicates that Youth A was at the program starting on 12/23/23 to
the present, Youth B entered the program on 5/15/23 and was
discharged on 3/29/24, Youth D entered the program on 8/21/23
13

to the present, and Youth E began the program on 7/13/23 to

Rule Code & CCI Rule 400.4128

Type
16

Allegation During this investigation, it was discovered that some staff have
not completed orientation, and some staff did not have the
required training hours.
Investigation Staff 1 was interviewed via phone on 8/23/2024 in
collaboration with MDHHS worker. Staff 1 reported there was
never a formal process for filling out incident reports or reporting
to MDHHS and she never received training on a process for doing
so. Staff 1 also reported not being trained on emergency drills and
having the fire alarm go off one evening and not knowing how to
handle the incident. She believed the only training she received
was when she was given a handbook of the rules and policies and
told to read it.
Staff 2 was interviewed via phone on 9/10/2024 in
collaboration with MDHHS worker. Staff 2 reported limited
training which involved her sitting down at a computer and going
through the policies at the beginning of her employment and then
never receiving any refresher trainings.
Documents Reviewed:
Staff 1’s personnel file: Documentation indicates Staff 1 was
hired on 1/25/2024 and there is no disciplinary action documents

hired on 3/3/23 and there is no disciplinary action documents in

Staff 3’s personnel file: Documentation indicates Staff 3 was

provided and 8 of the 10 do not meet the requirements of 50
